title: How do British royal 'Houses' work, like House of Tudor or House of Windsor? If all the Royals are related, why are there named distinctions like this? - Quora

response.answer_text: “How do British royal "Houses" work, like House of Tudor or House of Windsor? If all the Royals are related, why are there named distinctions like this?” Because house names follow male lines, and every so often the monarchy hasn’t followed the male line because a male line has died out. Keeping just with the English line since 1066 because I know what’s going on there without having to look stuff up: House of Normandy - expired with the death of Henry I without a male heir, was briefly replaced by the House of Blois via Henry I’s nephew (through his sister), then replaced by Henry I’s grandson through his daughter, namely Henry II of the… House of Plantagenet, which divided after a while into the cadet houses of York and Lancaster via Edmund of Langley, 1st Duke of York, and John of Gaunt, 1st Duke of Lancaster; neither man was ever king, but their descendants contested the claim for generations until their remnants were united under Henry VII, of the… House of Tudor, after Henry’s father Edmund Tudor, Earl of Richmond, who had married a descendant of John of Gaunt (in a line that had been barred from the throne, but Henry VII had a decent army, so he won). That house died out with the death of Elizabeth I, but Henry VII’s daughter Margaret had married into the… House of Stuart, giving her descendants in that line a claim and causing the Union of the Crowns. This House was briefly deposed after the Civil War but restored in 1660, but its direct (and non-Catholic, which mattered by this point) line died out with Queen Anne in 1714 and was replaced by the… House of Hanover, whose first English monarch (George I) had his claim through a female ancestor from the House of Stuart. The House of Hanover then hung around until it reached a woman, Victoria, who married Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, making her descendants the… House of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, which during the unpleasantness that was the First World War decided that the name was a teeeeeeeeeny bit too German, and renamed itself after one of its country seats, to give us the… House of Windsor.

It is simply that in British tradition, a wife takes her husband’s family name. When the last Tudor (Elizabeth I) died without children, the next in line was the descendant of her aunt Margaret, who had married a Stuart King of Scots. When the last Stuart (Anne) died childless, the next in line was the descendant of her aunt, and by then that was the House of Hanover. When Queen Victoria married Albert, the family name became his family name, Saxe-Coburg-Gotha. Windsor was chosen as a replacement for that because of anti-German feeling during WW1, but it remains the same family. Th present Queen has decided that it will continue to be Windsor, and not follow tradition and switch to her husband’s name (which is legally Mountbatten, though that was actually his mother’s family name, not his father’s).

Because they’re not, or only very distantly. The list of Monarchs is not an unbroken family tree. Rather, it is multiple families- the Plantagenets, the Tudors, the Saxeburg-Gothas etc-each of which has come to power, reigned for a bit, and then been deposed by someone else. Many of them are related, but so distantly that they may as well be.
To add to the other excellent answers and possibly the most important thing to remember, the British Monarchy is “NOTHING LIKE THE GAME OF THONES” where various houses compete.
